rev.comment: /* Social, legal and psychological views on necrophilia */
rev.diff:
Line 16: Line 16:
===Consensuality issue===
===Consensuality issue===
â
Although non-living material is not usually considered to be capable of, or require [[consent]], necrophilia is an exception to the rule in many people's eyes. A sexual act with a corpse is generally considered socially unacceptable; the presumption being that the person would not have consented to the act while alive and that it would constitute a profound and disturbing disrespect to them, and concern for others, for their remains to be treated in a way other than their presumed wishes.
+
Although obtaining consent is not usually considered a prerequisite for activity with non-living material, sexual activity with a human corpse is [[taboo]]<ref name="litera" /> and frequently labelled 'abuse,' based on the presumption that the person would not have consented to the act while alive, and that it would thus constitute a profound and disturbing disrespect for their remains to be treated in a way other than their wishes.
â
Virtually all human [[society|societies]] condemn abuse of the dead as a form of symbolic disrespect. In rare cases, however, necrophiliac acts can be consensual: for example, in the [[Armin Meiwes]] case, the victim gave his consent to the mutilation and death inflicted upon him.
+
Virtually all human [[society|societies]] condemn sexual activity with the dead as a form of symbolic disrespect. In rare cases, however, necrophilic acts can be consensual: for example, in the [[Armin Meiwes]] case, the victim gave his consent to the mutilation and death inflicted upon him.
===Necrophilia in neo-psychoanalysis===
===Necrophilia in neo-psychoanalysis===
